title: ARURF Club IS Pay to win.  URF is dead
body:
Paying for a pass for extra rerolls is paying to win.  Im really sorry this is very long-winded but please bear with me.

"Well you could get a worse champion" -

If you lost the champion you rolled it would make sense but starting with {{champion:32}} , into {{champion:77}}  into {{champion:60}} .  Still leaves you with {{champion:32}}  as your strongest pick.  There is only an advantage to rerolls.  There is literally no disadvtange so this arguement I keep hearing being brought up is absolutely bogus.  What if the order were to be {{champion:77}} {{champion:60}} {{champion:32}} ?  You would need the pass to get your "good" champion"




Here's another example, lets say you get {{champion:105}} .  What is stopping you from trading fizz to your friend or hitting roll and insta clicking fizz back in the pool and rolling a total of 2 champions if you will ALWAYS have 2 extra rolls? 

If your 3 (extremely unlikely but for the sake of arguement) rolls are {{champion:105}} {{champion:86}}  {{champion:238}} Everyone on your team takes advantage of you spending money.

If one team gets to choose from 10 random champs
And one team gets to choose from 15 random champs

I wonder who wins

I rest my case.

Closing statement:  Look at how they took URF with bans and hard bans, where yeah, a lot of the same 30ish champs were played but most people knew exactly what they were getting into every game and turned it into ARURF where the game is won in champ select because we got {{champion:60}} {{champion:154}} {{champion:27}} {{champion:14}} {{champion:33}} {{champion:429}} {{champion:48}}.  NOBODY WANTS TO PLAY THESE  they are ENTIRELY OUTCLASSED by and not fun against {{champion:99}} {{champion:43}} {{champion:161}}{{champion:238}} {{champion:12}} {{champion:24}}{{champion:110}} .
 AND THEN THEY TURN TO P2W on the whats supposed to be a crazy, fun, stressfree, lighthearted gamemode because they know deep deep down that going 1/13 as {{champion:77}}  wasnt your decision and you're not really having a whole lotta fun.  Why not spend $10 to have a little more fun ay?

replies.body: The URF pass is not pay to win. It's a colossal waste of money. You're paying $10 for meager bonuses in a timed event, with only an icon to keep. You're better off blowing that $10 on an actual skin.

Like i said previously: It's not P2W. You get rerolls after playing games. Paying players don't have to play one game without rerolls, but still have the same chance of getting trashy champs. Yes, it's stupid and pointless, but it's not pay to win.

You really don't understand this concept???

Imagine if one player gets to roll a d20 twice and gets to keep their highest number

And the other player gets to roll a d20 thrice and gets to keep their highest number

Over 100 turns the player who get to roll thrice will have an unfair advantage on the person who only gets to roll twice. Its not totally random dude. Its pay to win.

In the description of the golden spatula club, it says that the max rerolls you can do in a lobby is two.

All that means is a person playing urf with the club is guaranteed to have one reroll per game, whith the maximum still at two. You can still get two rerolls without paying for the pass, and calling it pay to win because of that is dumb.

You seem special bud. Late to the party, but here goes. URF works just like ARAM. You earn points per game towards rerolls. You can hold 2 rerolls. The URF pass simply gives you a free reroll every game, not exceeding the 2 cap, so if you held onto 2 rerolls via points, you do not get a third from the pass. Someone else without the pass, can also get 2 rerolls, they simply don't get the free one. AKA, all it really does is give you an average of 1.5 rerolls per game, where as someone without the pass has 0.5 rerolls per game. Capping at 2.

Yeah, the maximum at two, and the minimum no longer at zero. Someone with this pass will have more opportunities at stronger champs, and that is an in-game advantage. It's P2W plain and simple.

I object to calling it pay to win. There is no Pay wall preventing you from winning with out extra rerolls. 

Your correct, it is an advantage for a single account comparative to another single account.
The Lack of a reroll for teammates and enemys will be RNG,  For any individual match there is no assurance your Paid reroll is going to have any value or assist you in a win. It will be RNG.
Your example of 10 vs 15 is not reflective of reality of any match. A 5 man team could just as easily only have 1 set of rerolls even with all of them having the pass. You cant have more then 2 per game even with the pass.

Any individual game the advantage from the pass will be Random. Its never a BAD thing. But it does not inherently give you a win. It does not guaranty victory. 

Victory is not being held behind paywalls. So that's not PAY 2 WIN.

Im saying though if you have all champs and an urfpass you will always get 2 rerolls.

That person will/should roll twice every single match giving themselves/team 3 chances every game for a good champ.

I am not arguing its  not an advantage.  Your more then welcome to actively hate it. I am not sold its more of an advantage then a dedicated Aram account. Look, You are more then welcome to hate it. You don't have to like it. You can get upset at riot for it. There's nothing wrong with you viewing it as unfair.

Its very clearly not Pay to win however. There is no pay wall preventing victory for free users. Its not every top tier hero being Cash only unlocks. Its not having guns and gear with Stats always better then free items. Its not a fancy Boat/Spaceship/Tank with extra firepower hp ammo etc.

Plenty of Free to play games have advantages you can gain with $. Leauge for seasons 1-7 had rune pages. Running rune pages was a pre game advantage. Multiple pages for your main gave you better match up options vs not having them.

Over a long string of games this advantage could generate a higher win %.  Or not.  Just having the advantage was not and is not adequate to ensure a win.

That's Still not pay to win.

Your a Zerg main. New expansion comes out and new units fix the major issues with zerg playpatterns you use. You buy the expansion. Your now stronger and can win more games by using new unit types. Purchased power?

That's an advantage. That's also behind spending $. Do we ever call expansion packs Pay to win?  

I say no. I say pay to win is literally that, you have to pay to be able to win. You cant compete seriously otherwise.

Your welcome to disagreeing if you want, but I don't see how any one who has any experience with pay to win games would feel gold spatula club accomplishes this. And if your so nit picky about $ being spent on anything for an advantage you shoulda had beef with league from season 1.

So again, not asking you to like it. Just want to be clear that this is not a Pay to win Situation.

However, it's very clearly not pay to win. There is no pay wall preventing victory for free users. The stats aren't better than free items, and it's not like you get more opportunities for top tier heroes like you get with the ARURF pass. Over a long string of games, +30% crit chance could generate a higher win %. Or not. Just having the advantage was not and is not adequate to ensure a win. That's still not pay to win. Until anyone who doesn't pay cash is 100% guaranteed a loss and anyone who pays cash is instantly 100% guaranteed a win, it's totally fine to be selling a competitive advantage in a PvP game.

Totally not pay to win. I just want to be clear about that. It's just +30% crit chance. Feel free to disagree. But I want you to know that you're wrong. Because I'm right.

It's not a strawman at all. You can use the same arguments for and against it. It's a better chance of success that may not always pan out. Would it have been more understandable with a lower value, like +1% crit chance? Those +1% crit chance runes occasionally won lanes.

Arguing that it's a small competitive advantage - which you are doing when you repeat "it's only 0.6%" - is substantively different from arguing that it's not a competitive advantage.

It's not okay because it provides a competitive advantage in a PvP game, even a small advantage.

People aren't dumb for wanting an advantage. They're kind of unethical for buying it, but not nearly as Riot is being for offering it.

The maximum number of rerolls is two, but someone with an event pass isn't going to have zero rerolls for a match. That's the whole purpose behind this pass: _more rerolls_. That's what it does. And, once more, you're arguing that it's a _small_ competitive advantage to get more chances than other players do at turning a terrible URF champ into a great one, or even merely a better one.

Riot is testing the waters. If people buy this thing (and they are) and most of the playerbase says things like "it's not a competitive advantage because it's either zero or one extra rerolls which is just a chance at a better champ," do you really think they're not going to push it? P2W is a _gold mine_ that no company could ignore if it ever became a viable revenue strategy. As long as it's working, Riot will expand it. They're under enormous pressure to turn their shrinking business back into a growing one. Maybe the next time we see a pass like this, it'll increase the reroll cap to 3 or something. Baby steps.

The thing about the "definition" of P2W is that each person has a different "line in the sand" where they think it's no longer okay. Some people don't see any "pay to win" until paying guarantees winning and not paying guarantees losing. Others (such as myself) see even the slightest impingement of cash on gameplay as the introduction of P2W. For example, when WoW introduced its first non-service (e.g. name change) microtransaction, the Celestial Steed, I saw that as P2W. Someone who bought that mount no longer had to spend gold on any level of ground or flying mounts for any character on the account ever again, saving thousands that they could spend instead on gems, flasks, and so on. For most people, it's somewhere in the middle. Buying another roll of the dice for an OP champ (or just a stronger one) in a PvP mode of a PvP game is way over that middle line, but for now we're seeing desperate rationalizations as people move the goalposts to excuse this.

It provides a competitive advantage in a PvP game for cash, which is P2W, and it's disgusting that we've come to this, especially after LoL has been so resistant to it for so long.

Since this is a competitive PvP game rather than an NPC stomp, the only way to make guarantees like that is to grant victory to whoever pays _more_. However, even a small advantage in a PvP game ruins the competition, and it becomes "whoever spent (more) money is more likely to win," which is why other people have a problem with this.

The "change" the pass grants you in your chances of getting the champion you want is an _increase_, making it a competitive advantage, however slight. Do you know the difference between "zero" and "not zero"? It's very important.

Yes it does. The "extra chance at getting what you want" is a chance for stronger champions, which have a huge impact in a mode like URF. Some champs are mediocre in URF, others are terrible, others are fantastic. An extra roll of the dice to possibly change your Karthus to a Vel'Koz is an advantage that non-payers won't have (note, an _extra_ roll of the dice, which is what the pass provides).

Calling people dumb for thinking this provides an advantage when it does is an ad hominem, and, since I've clearly been saying that it provides an advantage, it's specifically an insult to to me.

"I am just as likely to get Evelynn as I was before the re-rolls because of how statistically insignificant the advantage would be" LOLOLOL. The chance is small, therefore it is zero! Are you for real? Calling people dumb and then confusing numbers that are zero with numbers that aren't zero?

Riot will increase the advantages you can get from paying money if it's profitable. If they gain more income from selling these things than they do from people leaving due to P2W, there's no sound business reason not to. Some people will pay a _lot_ of money for competitive advantages, so if the backlash is pretty limited and shouted down by insistence that it's not P2W, it'll be worth it, and Riot should do it, because they're a business.

If you think that P2W only applies on guaranteed wins and losses, you'll basically never think anything is P2W. There could be armor in a cash shop granting +1000 all stats, and that doesn't guarantee a win (that person could troll, AFK, etc.), so it wouldn't be P2W by your definition. However, it's a competitive advantage (an enormous one), and anyone who values the integrity of a PvP game would have a problem with that.

Telling me that the statement that being able to buy advantages in a game means P2W "is objectively wrong to state and is wrong" is just redundant babbling with no substance (after you call anyone who disagrees with you "dumb").

Calling the purchase of competitive advantages in a PvP game "P2W" isn't "utterly ridiculous." You just don't have any argument other than logical fallacies. Frankly, I'm tired of your obstinacy and your rudeness, and I'm done talking to you here. Goodbye.
